dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: Mainly found in freshwater, sometimes in brackish parts of lagoons and mangrove coastlines (Ref. 26938).  Moves in schools (Ref. 26938).  Feeds on insects (Ref. 7020), other invertebrates and diatoms living on the mud, and small fishes (Ref. 35237).  Can remain on mud bottom exposed to air during low tide (Ref. 26938).  Used in eye research (Ref. 4537).  Often travels in schools (Ref. 26938).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: South America:  Trinidad and Venezuela to the Amazon delta in Brazil.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: Brazil, French Guiana, Guyana, Suriname, Trinidad and Tobago, and Venezuela.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Size
dataObjects.title: Max. size
dataObjects.description: 30.0 cm TL (male/unsexed; (Ref. 35237)); max. published weight: 400 g (Ref. 35237)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObjects.description: Eye divided into aerial and aquatic parts.  Fewer than 80 scales in row above lateral line (Ref. 26938).

dataObjects.references: Zurlo, G. 1995 Zur Fortpflanzungsbiologie von Vieraugenfischen. p. 165-171. In H. Greven and R. Riehl (eds.) Fortpflanzungsbiologie der Aquarienfische. Birgit Schmettkamp Verlag, Bornheim, Germany.

dataObjects.subject: http://www.eol.org/voc/table_of_contents#FunctionalAdaptations
dataObjects.title: Functional adaptation
dataObjects.description:
Eyes see above and below water surface: four-eyed fish
 

Split eyes of the four-eyed fish allow it to see above and below the surface of the water simultaneously due to varying thickness in the lens.

 
Process information > Sense signals/environmental cues > Light - visible spectrum 
 
  "Native to Caribbean lagoons, Anableps anableps is commonly known as the four-eyed fish because its two eyes are split by horizontal partitions into two halves, each of which has its own iris and retina. This unique optical construction lets the fish swim at the surface of the water, with the upper half of each eye scanning the air for predatory fish-eating birds, and the lower half peering down below the surface, in search of small fish to feed on…Despite each eye being partitioned, there is only one oval-shaped lens per eye. Because vision through water requires a thicker lens than vision through air, the fish's eye is ingeniously adapted to fulfill two purposes, with the lower portion of each eye's lens (through which the fish sees underwater) thicker than the upper portion (through which the fish sees in air)." (Shuker 2001:12-13)
  Learn more about this functional adaptation.
dataObjects.references: Shuker, KPN.  2001.  The Hidden Powers of Animals: Uncovering the Secrets of Nature.  London: Marshall Editions Ltd.  240 p.
